section.title: Linear and Exponential Growth
section.p: Let b,m be real constants, and consider the linear function L(t)=b+mt. The sequence of values L(0), L(1), L(2),\ldots given by b, b+m, b+2m,\ldots ,b+nm,\ldots is called an arithmetic sequencearithmetic sequenceThe emphasis is on the third syllable met when the word arithmetic is used as an adjective rather than a noun. For example: Addition is an operation of \mbox{a}\cdot \mbox{rith}'\cdot \mbox{metic}. Repeated addition creates an \mbox{arith}\cdot \mbox{met}'\cdot \mbox{ic} sequence. with initial terminitial term of an arithmetic sequence b and common differencecommon difference in an arithmetic sequence m. An arithmetic sequence is said to exhibit linearlinear growth or decay growth or decay, according to whether m \gt 0 or m\lt 0, respectively.

Let a,r be real constants with a\neq 0, r\gt 0, r\neq 1, and consider the exponential function E(t) = ar^t. The sequence of values E(0),E(1),E(2),\ldots given by a,ar,ar^2,\ldots,ar^n,\ldots is called a geometric sequencegeometric sequence with initial terminitial term of a geometric sequence a and common ratiocommon ratio in a geometric sequence r. A geometric sequence with a\gt 0 is said to exhibit exponentialexponential growth or decay growth or decay, according to whether r\gt 1 or r\lt 1, respectively.

section.p:
Infinite geometric sums. An infinite sum of the form a + ar + ar^2 + ar^3 + \cdots is called an infinite geometric seriesinfinite geometric series, and is defined to mean \displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty} s_n (if the limit exists), where s_1,s_2,s_3,\ldots is sequence of finite sums s_0 \amp = a s_1 \amp = a + ar s_2 \amp = a + ar + ar^2 \amp \vdots s_n \amp = a+ ar+ar^2 + \cdots + ar^n \amp \vdots
If |r| \lt 1, then |r|^n \to 0 as n\to \infty. Using properties of limits from calculus, we have a\left(\frac{1-r^{n+1}}{1-r} \right) \to a\left(\frac{1}{1-r}\right) as n\to \infty. Putting this together with above is the justification for the following formula. a + ar+ ar^2 + ar^3 + \cdots = a\left(\frac{1}{1-r}\right) \amp \amp \mbox{ for } |r|\lt 1

hint.p: Write the sum in reverse order L(n)+L(n-1) + \cdots + L(1) + L(0) directly beneath L(0)+ L(1) + \cdots + L(n), in such a way that the terms are aligned vertically. Notice that each vertically aligned pair has the form L(k) and L(n-k), and that L(k)+L(n-k) = 2b+nm (the k's cancel!). Now go from there.

aside.title: Instructor's solution for
aside.p:
Let s=\sum_{k=0}^n L(k) be the desired sum. Then we have 2s \amp = \sum_{k=0}^n L(k)+ \sum_{k=0}^n L(n-k) \amp = \sum_{k=0}^n (L(k)+L(n-k)) \amp = \sum_{k=0}^n (b+mk+b+m(n-k))) \amp = \sum_{k=0}^n (2b+nm) \amp = (2b+nm)(n+1).
It follows that s= \frac{(2b+nm)(n+1)}{2},
as desired.

hint.p: Let s be the desired sum a+ar+ar^2 + \cdots + ar^n. Examine the expansion of s-rs (many terms cancel!). Simplify and solve for s.

aside.title: Instructor's solution for
aside.p: We have s=\sum_{k=0}^n ar^n, so sr=\sum_{k=0}^n ar^{n+1} = \sum_{k=1}^{n+1} ar^{n}. Thus we have s(1-r) = s-rs = \sum_{k=0}^n ar^n - \sum_{k=1}^{n+1} ar^{n} = a-ar^{n+1}. It follows that s = a\left(\frac{1-r^{n+1}}{1-r}\right), as claimed.

statement.p: The sequence L(n) for n=1,2,3,\ldots satisfies the recursive relation L(n+1)=L(n)+m. (A recursive relation says how the next entry in a sequence is determined by one or more previous entries.) The sequence E(n) for n=1,2,3,\ldots satisfies the recursive relation E(n+1)=rE(n). Suppose that there is a function M(t) that satisfies the recursive relation M(n+1)=rM(n)+m for n=1,2,3,\ldots. Find a formula for M(t) in terms of M_0=M(0),r,m.

aside.title: Instructor's solution for
aside.p:
The first few terms of the sequence M(0),M(1),M(2),\ldots are the following.
M(0) \amp = M_0\\ M(1) \amp = rM_0+m\\ M(2) \amp = r(rM_0+m) + m\\ M(3) \amp = r[r(rM_0+m) + m]+m
Notice that M(3) = r^3M_0 + m(r^2+r+1). You can see this pattern holds in general, so we have
M(n) \amp = r^nM_0 + m(1+r+r^2 + \cdots r^{n-1})\\ \amp = r^nM_0 + m\left(\frac{1-r^{n}}{1-r}\right)\\ \amp = r^n\left(M_0 - \frac{m}{r-1}\right) + \frac{m}{r-1}.
Thus we have M(t) = \left(M_0 - \frac{m}{r-1}\right)r^t + \frac{m}{r-1}.
